member.name: T:Emby.Server.Implementations.Data.SynchronousMode
member.summary: The disk synchronization mode, controls how aggressively SQLite will write data all the way out to physical storage.

member.name: F:Emby.Server.Implementations.Data.SynchronousMode.Off
member.summary: SQLite continues without syncing as soon as it has handed data off to the operating system.

member.name: F:Emby.Server.Implementations.Data.SynchronousMode.Normal
member.summary: SQLite database engine will still sync at the most critical moments.

member.name: F:Emby.Server.Implementations.Data.SynchronousMode.Full
member.summary: SQLite database engine will use the xSync method of the VFS to ensure that all content is safely written to the disk surface prior to continuing.

member.name: F:Emby.Server.Implementations.Data.SynchronousMode.Extra
member.summary: EXTRA synchronous is like FULL with the addition that the directory containing a rollback journal is synced after that journal is unlinked to commit a transaction in DELETE mode.

member.name: T:Emby.Server.Implementations.Data.TempStoreMode
member.summary: Storage mode used by temporary database files.

member.name: F:Emby.Server.Implementations.Data.TempStoreMode.Default
member.summary: The compile-time C preprocessor macro SQLITE_TEMP_STORE is used to determine where temporary tables and indices are stored.

member.name: F:Emby.Server.Implementations.Data.TempStoreMode.File
member.summary: Temporary tables and indices are stored in a file.

member.name: F:Emby.Server.Implementations.Data.TempStoreMode.Memory
member.summary: Temporary tables and indices are kept in as if they were pure in-memory databases memory.
